elements.content: Highly porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [Cu3(MBTC)2(H2O)3] n (where MBTC is methyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and [Cu3(EBTC)2(H2O)3] n (where EBTC is ethyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) have been solvothermally synthesized. The MOFs are isostructural to each other but do not form the same framework as HKUST-1 (CuBTC) due to the steric impact of the alkyl-functionalized ligands. The new MOFs are formed by two different [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (where R is an aromatic ring), which create the three-dimensional framework with open-metal sites and high surface areas. Compared with HKUST-1, these MOFs adsorb comparable amounts of carbon dioxide and methane at pressures up to 5 bar. However, water adsorption is significantly lower compared to HKUST-1 due to the hydrophobic functional groups. This work indicates that the strong adsorption preference of water on open-metal sites can be limited with the proper choice of the hydrophobic functional groups, without losing the strong interaction with other gases.
elements.clean_text: Highly porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [Cu3(MBTC)2(H2O)3] n  (where MBTC is methyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and [Cu3(EBTC)2(H2O)3] n  (where EBTC is ethyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) have been solvothermally synthesized. The MOFs are isostructural to each other but do not form the same framework as HKUST-1 (CuBTC) due to the steric impact of the alkyl-functionalized ligands. The new MOFs are formed by two different [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (where R is an aromatic ring), which create the three-dimensional framework with open-metal sites and high surface areas. Compared with HKUST-1, these MOFs adsorb comparable amounts of carbon dioxide and methane at pressures up to 5 bar. However, water adsorption is significantly lower compared to HKUST-1 due to the hydrophobic functional groups. This work indicates that the strong adsorption preference of water on open-metal sites can be limited with the proper choice of the hydrophobic functional groups, without losing the strong interaction with other gases.

elements.content: Highly porous metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) [Cu3(MBTC)2(H2O)3] n (where MBTC is methyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and [Cu3(EBTC)2(H2O)3] n (where EBTC is ethyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) have been solvothermally synthesized. The MOFs are isostructural to each other but do not form the same framework as HKUST-1 (CuBTC) due to the steric impact of the alkyl-functionalized ligands. The new MOFs are formed by two different [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (where R is an aromatic ring), which create the three-dimensional (3D) framework with open-metal sites and high surface areas. Compared with HKUST-1, these MOFs adsorb comparable amounts of carbon dioxide and methane at pressures up to 5 bar. However, water adsorption is significantly lower compared to HKUST-1 due to the hydrophobic functional groups.
elements.clean_text: Highly porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [Cu3(MBTC)2(H2O)3] n  (where MBTC is methyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) and [Cu3(EBTC)2(H2O)3] n  (where EBTC is ethyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) have been solvothermally synthesized. The MOFs are isostructural to each other but do not form the same framework as HKUST-1 (CuBTC) due to the steric impact of the alkyl-functionalized ligands. The new MOFs are formed by two different [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (where R is an aromatic ring), which create the three-dimensional (3D) framework with open-metal sites and high surface areas. Compared with HKUST-1, these MOFs adsorb comparable amounts of carbon dioxide and methane at pressures up to 5 bar. However, water adsorption is significantly lower compared to HKUST-1 due to the hydrophobic functional groups.

elements.content: Porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention in recent years due to their potential applications in gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, selective adsorption, and sensor technology. One outstanding challenge in the synthesis of porous adsorbents is the systematic design of specific pore sizes and adsorption functionalities. MOFs offer the potential for such designer adsorbents compared to conventional porous materials due to flexible synthesis techniques in which the metal and/or organic ligand can be tailored to impart specific properties. The first example of isostructural MOFs was the IRMOF series, in which the MOF-5 ligand (benzene-dicarboxylic acid, BDC) was functionalized with the organic groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, and -C2H4, and its pore size was expanded with long molecular struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl without changing the underlying topology.
elements.clean_text: Porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention in recent years due to their potential applications in gas storage, heterogeneous catalysis, selective adsorption, and sensor technology. One outstanding challenge in the synthesis of porous adsorbents is the systematic design of specific pore sizes and adsorption functionalities. MOFs offer the potential for such designer adsorbents compared to conventional porous materials due to flexible synthesis techniques in which the metal and/or organic ligand can be tailored to impart specific properties. The first example of isostructural MOFs was the IRMOF series, in which the MOF-5 ligand (benzene-dicarboxylic acid, BDC) was functionalized with the organic groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, and -C2H4, and its pore size was expanded with long molecular struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl without changing the underlying topology.

elements.content: Since the MOF-5 report, a variety of MOF structures have been synthesized and studied in the past several years. HKUST-1 (CuBTC), first reported by Chui et al., is one of the most widely studied MOFs. It is built from the paddle-wheel cluster consisting of Cu2+ ions coordinated to 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate organic linkers (BTC), forming an exceptionally rigid and highly porous network (shown in Figure ) with a high specific surface area. H3BTC is a multidentate linker that allows for the formation of rigid frameworks through aggregation of metal ions into M–O–C clusters. After synthesis, the remaining coordination sites (one per Cu atom) are occupied by water molecules, which can be removed by heating under a vacuum. The removal of coordinated water reveals the open-metal sites, which are known to enhance the ability of the materials to adsorb particular molecules. Many other copper-based MOFs containing m-benzenedicarboxylate moieties possess open metal sites, which have a strong affinity for specific gas molecules. Adsorption properties of HKUST-1 for a variety of sorbate molecules including N2, O2, CO, CO2, N2O, CH4, C2H6, C2H4, n-dodecane, and water have been studied since the first report over a decade ago. Compared with other MOFs that do not possess open-metal sites, HKUST-1 has exhibited high adsorption selectivity for CO2 over CO and N2 at low pressure. However, the open-metal sites also have a strong affinity for water, which will decrease the capacity for other gases when present in a mixture. Recent research has focused on the modification of HKUST-1 postsynthesis to introduce accessible secondary amine functionalities that react with nitric oxide (NO). However, the open metal coordination sites of the derivation are occupied by the functionalities.
elements.clean_text: Since the MOF-5 report, a variety of MOF structures have been synthesized and studied in the past several years. HKUST-1 (CuBTC), first reported by Chui et al., is one of the most widely studied MOFs. It is built from the paddle-wheel cluster consisting of Cu2+ ions coordinated to 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate organic linkers (BTC), forming an exceptionally rigid and highly porous network (shown in Figure ) with a high specific surface area. H3BTC is a multidentate linker that allows for the formation of rigid frameworks through aggregation of metal ions into M-O-C clusters. After synthesis, the remaining coordination sites (one per Cu atom) are occupied by water molecules, which can be removed by heating under a vacuum. The removal of coordinated water reveals the open-metal sites, which are known to enhance the ability of the materials to adsorb particular molecules. Many other copper-based MOFs containing m-benzenedicarboxylate moieties possess open metal sites, which have a strong affinity for specific gas molecules. Adsorption properties of HKUST-1 for a variety of sorbate molecules including N2, O2, CO, CO2, N2O, CH4, C2H6, C2H4, n-dodecane, and water have been studied since the first report over a decade ago. Compared with other MOFs that do not possess open-metal sites, HKUST-1 has exhibited high adsorption selectivity for CO2 over CO and N2 at low pressure. However, the open-metal sites also have a strong affinity for water, which will decrease the capacity for other gases when present in a mixture. Recent research has focused on the modification of HKUST-1 postsynthesis to introduce accessible secondary amine functionalities that react with nitric oxide (NO). However, the open metal coordination sites of the derivation are occupied by the functionalities.

elements.content: The crystal structure of HKUST-1 along the [100] direction.
elements.clean_text: 1  The crystal structure of HKUST-1 along the [100] direction.

elements.content: Functionalization of MOF ligands, similar to the MOF-5/IRMOF family, can impact the adsorption properties of the MOF and can also provide sites for postsynthetic modification. However, there have been no reports of functionalizing the BTC ligand of HKUST-1. Here, we report two isostructural copper-frameworks constructed from H3BTC that has been functionalized with methyl (-CH3) or ethyl (-C2H5) groups (Scheme ). Because of the presence of these alkyl functional groups, the angles between carboxylic groups on the benzene ring are no longer 120°; the torsion angles are now 135° for CuMBTC and 144° for CuEBTC. Because of steric effects, the main pore of HKUST-1 cannot tolerate four functional groups in a single pore. Thus, CuMBTC and CuEBTC assemble into isostructures that are distinct from HKUST-1. For the famous BDC ligand, it has been shown that substituted moieties next to the carboxylates in MOFs can change the structure topology of materials. However, even without the same underlying topology as HKUST-1, these two new materials do possess the same M–O–C cluster, open-metal sites, and similar porosity as HKUST-1. As a result, the CO2 and CH4 adsorption behaviors up to 5 bar are comparable to HKUST-1, but the water adsorption loadings are significantly reduced due to the alkyl functional groups.
elements.clean_text: Functionalization of MOF ligands, similar to the MOF-5/IRMOF family, can impact the adsorption properties of the MOF and can also provide sites for postsynthetic modification. However, there have been no reports of functionalizing the BTC ligand of HKUST-1. Here, we report two isostructural copper-frameworks constructed from H3BTC that has been functionalized with methyl (-CH3) or ethyl (-C2H5) groups (Scheme ). Because of the presence of these alkyl functional groups, the angles between carboxylic groups on the benzene ring are no longer 120°; the torsion angles are now 135° for CuMBTC and 144° for CuEBTC. Because of steric effects, the main pore of HKUST-1 cannot tolerate four functional groups in a single pore. Thus, CuMBTC and CuEBTC assemble into isostructures that are distinct from HKUST-1. For the famous BDC ligand, it has been shown that substituted moieties next to the carboxylates in MOFs can change the structure topology of materials. However, even without the same underlying topology as HKUST-1, these two new materials do possess the same M-O-C cluster, open-metal sites, and similar porosity as HKUST-1. As a result, the CO2 and CH4 adsorption behaviors up to 5 bar are comparable to HKUST-1, but the water adsorption loadings are significantly reduced due to the alkyl functional groups.

elements.content: Functionalization of H3BTC with methyl or ethyl groups as shown in Scheme was performed using synthesis procedures described in the . Blue crystals of [Cu3(MBTC)2(H2O)3] and [Cu3(EBTC)2(H2O)3] were then synthesized from the reaction of H3MBTC (H3MBTC is methyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) or H3EBTC (H3EBTC is ethyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) with Cu(NO3)2·3H2O at 120 °C (see for details). The MOFs form body-centered-orthorhombic crystals that possess 3D channels. The experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of bulk samples of CuMBTC and CuEBTC match the simulated patterns from single crystal structure data relatively well, as shown in Figure . TGA experiments show that the compounds are stable up to 300 °C under inert gas flow (see Figure S3 in ).
elements.clean_text: Functionalization of H3BTC with methyl or ethyl groups as shown in Scheme  was performed using synthesis procedures described in the . Blue crystals of [Cu3(MBTC)2(H2O)3] and [Cu3(EBTC)2(H2O)3] were then synthesized from the reaction of H3MBTC (H3MBTC is methyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) or H3EBTC (H3EBTC is ethyl-1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) with Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O at 120 °C (see  for details). The MOFs form body-centered-orthorhombic crystals that possess 3D channels. The experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of bulk samples of CuMBTC and CuEBTC match the simulated patterns from single crystal structure data relatively well, as shown in Figure . TGA experiments show that the compounds are stable up to 300 °C under inert gas flow (see Figure S3 in ).

elements.content: XRD patterns of CuMBTC (a) and CuEBTC (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  XRD patterns of CuMBTC (a) and CuEBTC (b).

elements.content: Single-crystal structure analyses reveal that these two MOFs share the same underlying topology. The framework of CuMBTC is composed of two different dimeric cupric tetracarboxylate units, as shown in Figure . Cu1 and Cu1a (Cu2 and Cu2b) are each coordinated by one water molecule and four oxygen atoms from carboxyl groups. Each copper completes its pseudooctahedral coordination sphere with an axial aqua ligand opposite to the Cu–Cu vector. The modified BTC provides a 2-fold symmetry element rather than 3-fold due to the presence of the methyl groups. Cu12(O2C)4 units and methyl groups are at ortho positions of the aromatic rings with a short Cu1–Cu1a internuclear separation of 2.65 Å, while Cu22(O2C)4 units and methyl groups are at para positions of aromatic rings with a Cu2–Cu2b internuclear separation of 2.65 Å. As shown in Figure a, one tetracarboxylate unit provides a structural motif with potential 4-fold symmetry. The other unit forms 2-fold rotational symmetry along the line perpendicular to the Cu1–Cu1a vector in Figure b. However, it does not form the same octahedral secondary building units (SBUs) as HKUST-1. Instead, the origin of the nanometer-sized channels can be considered as arising from the formation of smaller SBUs. As shown in Figure a, the key SBU in CuMBTC is a pyramidal unit with Cu12 dimers at its four bottom vertices, Cu22 dimers at the top vertices of the pyramid, and two benzene rings at two of the four pyramidal faces of the pyramid. CuEBTC shares similar dimeric cupric tetracarboxylate units and SBUs with CuMBTC as shown in and Figure b.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal structure analyses reveal that these two MOFs share the same underlying topology. The framework of CuMBTC is composed of two different dimeric cupric tetracarboxylate units, as shown in Figure . Cu1 and Cu1a (Cu2 and Cu2b) are each coordinated by one water molecule and four oxygen atoms from carboxyl groups. Each copper completes its pseudooctahedral coordination sphere with an axial aqua ligand opposite to the Cu-Cu vector. The modified BTC provides a 2-fold symmetry element rather than 3-fold due to the presence of the methyl groups. Cu12(O2C)4 units and methyl groups are at ortho positions of the aromatic rings with a short Cu1-Cu1a internuclear separation of 2.65 Å, while Cu22(O2C)4 units and methyl groups are at para positions of aromatic rings with a Cu2-Cu2b internuclear separation of 2.65 Å. As shown in Figure a, one tetracarboxylate unit provides a structural motif with potential 4-fold symmetry. The other unit forms 2-fold rotational symmetry along the line perpendicular to the Cu1-Cu1a vector in Figure b. However, it does not form the same octahedral secondary building units (SBUs) as HKUST-1. Instead, the origin of the nanometer-sized channels can be considered as arising from the formation of smaller SBUs. As shown in Figure a, the key SBU in CuMBTC is a pyramidal unit with Cu12 dimers at its four bottom vertices, Cu22 dimers at the top vertices of the pyramid, and two benzene rings at two of the four pyramidal faces of the pyramid. CuEBTC shares similar dimeric cupric tetracarboxylate units and SBUs with CuMBTC as shown in  and Figure b.

elements.content: (a, b) Two different dicopper(II) tetracarboxylate building blocks of CuMBTC.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a, b) Two different dicopper(II) tetracarboxylate building blocks of CuMBTC.

elements.content: Secondary building units for CuMBTC (a) and CuEBTC (b).
elements.clean_text: 4  Secondary building units for CuMBTC (a) and CuEBTC (b).

elements.content: The final framework is achieved by connecting the SBU with other units through corner sharing of the pyramidal system. In Figure a, a view down the [001] direction of the cubic unit cell of CuMBTC reveals ∼1-nm-size channels with 2-fold symmetry. Using the copper atoms of the paddle-wheel clusters as the points of “rectangularity”, the edges were measured as 9.14 Å and 8.83 Å and 12.71 Å across its diagonal. The channels intersect to provide a 3D connected network of pores. The main channels are formed by connecting the cages shown in Figure a through the windows shown in Figure b. As shown in Figure b, CuEBTC has the same topology as CuMBTC but with a different size and functionality. For CuEBTC, the edges of the rectangularity and its diagonal were measured as 9.43 Å, 7.78 Å, and 12.22 Å, respectively. As suggested by the crystallographic measurements, the channels of CuEBTC are stretched slightly in the [010] direction, which results in a slight compression of the channel diameter in the [100] direction.
elements.clean_text: The final framework is achieved by connecting the SBU with other units through corner sharing of the pyramidal system. In Figure a, a view down the [001] direction of the cubic unit cell of CuMBTC reveals ~1-nm-size channels with 2-fold symmetry. Using the copper atoms of the paddle-wheel clusters as the points of "rectangularity", the edges were measured as 9.14 Å and 8.83 Å and 12.71 Å across its diagonal. The channels intersect to provide a 3D connected network of pores. The main channels are formed by connecting the cages shown in Figure a through the windows shown in Figure b. As shown in Figure b, CuEBTC has the same topology as CuMBTC but with a different size and functionality. For CuEBTC, the edges of the rectangularity and its diagonal were measured as 9.43 Å, 7.78 Å, and 12.22 Å, respectively. As suggested by the crystallographic measurements, the channels of CuEBTC are stretched slightly in the [010] direction, which results in a slight compression of the channel diameter in the [100] direction.

elements.content: Desolvation of the compounds was achieved by heating to 170 °C for 8 h under a vacuum. The MOFs undergo a color change from turquoise to dark blue, similar to HKUST-1. As shown in Figure , there is a slight difference in intensity of the peaks in the PXRD patterns after activation compared to the as-synthesized sample, but the general agreement of the major peaks, along with surface area measurements, suggests that the structures remain intact. The anhydrates are stable under dry air, and the samples rehydrate on exposure to humid air. The experimentally determined adsorption properties of CuMBTC and CuEBTC are consistent with the high porosity indicated by their crystal structures. Nitrogen isotherm measurements at 77 K gave pore volumes and BET surface areas of 0.78 cm3 g–1 and 1471 m2 g–1 for CuMBTC, and 0.65 cm3 g–1 and 1434 m2 g–1 for CuEBTC (see for N2 isotherms). The experimentally determined BET surface areas are also in good agreement with the accessible surface areas, which are 1783 m2 g–1 for CuMBTC and 1667 m2 g–1 for CuEBTC, calculated from the single-crystal structure with a nitrogen sized probe molecule.
elements.clean_text: Desolvation of the compounds was achieved by heating to 170 °C for 8 h under a vacuum. The MOFs undergo a color change from turquoise to dark blue, similar to HKUST-1. As shown in Figure , there is a slight difference in intensity of the peaks in the PXRD patterns after activation compared to the as-synthesized sample, but the general agreement of the major peaks, along with surface area measurements, suggests that the structures remain intact. The anhydrates are stable under dry air, and the samples rehydrate on exposure to humid air. The experimentally determined adsorption properties of CuMBTC and CuEBTC are consistent with the high porosity indicated by their crystal structures. Nitrogen isotherm measurements at 77 K gave pore volumes and BET surface areas of 0.78 cm3 g-1 and 1471 m2 g-1 for CuMBTC, and 0.65 cm3 g-1 and 1434 m2 g-1 for CuEBTC (see  for N2 isotherms). The experimentally determined BET surface areas are also in good agreement with the accessible surface areas, which are 1783 m2 g-1 for CuMBTC and 1667 m2 g-1 for CuEBTC, calculated from the single-crystal structure with a nitrogen sized probe molecule.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms for CO2, CH4, and water vapor at 298 K were measured on the two new MOFs and compared with isotherms for the same sorbates on HKUST-1. MOFs have received considerable attention in recent years for CO2 capture and gas storage applications. MOF-177 was shown to have a volumetric adsorption capacity for CO2 that was substantially higher at high pressure than that of commercial materials such as zeolite 13X and activated carbon. However, because the CO2 partial pressures in flue exhaust or natural gas are usually under 1 bar, it is important to examine CO2 adsorption in MOF materials in the low pressure region. Adsorption isotherms for CO2 and CH4 on CuMBTC and CuEBTC display approximately type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and adsorption saturation was almost reached near 20 bar. Figure a shows that CuMBTC and CuEBTC have slightly lower loadings of CO2 and CH4 than HKUST-1 at high pressure due to the surface area and pore volume differences. However, they have comparable CH4 and CO2 adsorption capability as HKUST-1 at low pressure (below 5 bar), as shown in Figure b.
elements.clean_text: Adsorption isotherms for CO2, CH4, and water vapor at 298 K were measured on the two new MOFs and compared with isotherms for the same sorbates on HKUST-1. MOFs have received considerable attention in recent years for CO2 capture and gas storage applications. MOF-177 was shown to have a volumetric adsorption capacity for CO2 that was substantially higher at high pressure than that of commercial materials such as zeolite 13X and activated carbon. However, because the CO2 partial pressures in flue exhaust or natural gas are usually under 1 bar, it is important to examine CO2 adsorption in MOF materials in the low pressure region. Adsorption isotherms for CO2 and CH4 on CuMBTC and CuEBTC display approximately type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and adsorption saturation was almost reached near 20 bar. Figure a shows that CuMBTC and CuEBTC have slightly lower loadings of CO2 and CH4 than HKUST-1 at high pressure due to the surface area and pore volume differences. However, they have comparable CH4 and CO2 adsorption capability as HKUST-1 at low pressure (below 5 bar), as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms for CO2 and CH4 in HKUST-1, CuMBTC, and CuEBTC at 298 K (closed symbols-adsorption; open symbols-desorption): (a) 0–20 bar and (b) 0–5 bar.
elements.clean_text: 7  Adsorption isotherms for CO2 and CH4 in HKUST-1, CuMBTC, and CuEBTC at 298 K (closed symbols-adsorption; open symbols-desorption): (a) 0-20 bar and (b) 0-5 bar.

elements.content: Water vapor is typically present at various levels in CO2-containing streams such as flue gas. While the open-metal sites are known to interact favorably with CO2, the interaction with water is even more favorable. As a result, water will typically adsorb preferentially over CO2 in MOFs with open-metal sites, leading to lower adsorption capacity for CO2. Thus, limiting or preventing water uptake will improve the selectivity and capacity of the MOF for CO2. The water isotherms for HKUST-1, CuMBTC, and CuEBTC are shown in Figure . Because of the functional groups -CH3 and -C2H5, the decrease in water adsorption for CuMBTC and CuEBTC compared to HKUST-1 is pronounced. High adsorption loadings at high concentrations are typically a function of large pore volume. However, the pore volume differences between HKUST-1 (0.828 cm3g–1) and CuMBTC (0.7853 cm3g–1) and CuEBTC (0.6472 cm3g–1) cannot totally account for the fact that HKUST-1 adsorbs triple the amount of water compared to the two functionalized MOFs. Clearly, the alkyl functional groups extending from BTC into the pore space are depressing the water adsorption, in spite of the large porosity and presence of open-metal sites. As shown in Figure , the PXRD patterns do not change significantly from the activated sample after exposure to 90% relative humidity.
elements.clean_text: Water vapor is typically present at various levels in CO2-containing streams such as flue gas. While the open-metal sites are known to interact favorably with CO2, the interaction with water is even more favorable. As a result, water will typically adsorb preferentially over CO2 in MOFs with open-metal sites, leading to lower adsorption capacity for CO2. Thus, limiting or preventing water uptake will improve the selectivity and capacity of the MOF for CO2. The water isotherms for HKUST-1, CuMBTC, and CuEBTC are shown in Figure . Because of the functional groups -CH3 and -C2H5, the decrease in water adsorption for CuMBTC and CuEBTC compared to HKUST-1 is pronounced. High adsorption loadings at high concentrations are typically a function of large pore volume. However, the pore volume differences between HKUST-1 (0.828 cm3g-1) and CuMBTC (0.7853 cm3g-1) and CuEBTC (0.6472 cm3g-1) cannot totally account for the fact that HKUST-1 adsorbs triple the amount of water compared to the two functionalized MOFs. Clearly, the alkyl functional groups extending from BTC into the pore space are depressing the water adsorption, in spite of the large porosity and presence of open-metal sites. As shown in Figure , the PXRD patterns do not change significantly from the activated sample after exposure to 90% relative humidity.

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms for H2O in HKUST-1, CuMBTC, and CuEBTC at 293 K (closed symbols for adsorption and open symbols for desorption).
elements.clean_text: 8  Adsorption isotherms for H2O in HKUST-1, CuMBTC, and CuEBTC at 293 K (closed symbols for adsorption and open symbols for desorption).

elements.content: The main pore of HKUST-1 has a diameter of approximately 9 Å, which is quite similar to the main channel openings in CuMBTC and CuEBTC. It has been shown through experiments and molecular modeling studies that while electrostatic effects from open-metal sites play a significant role in CO2 adsorption at low pressure, van der Waals forces are still large contributors overall. Thus, the presence of the alkyl functional groups in the pore space enhances these van der Waals interactions, leading to high uptake of CO2 at low pressure. However, the alkyl groups depress water adsorption under the same conditions. As a result, compared to HKUST-1, these alkyl-functionalized MOFs have comparable CO2 and CH4 gas adsorption properties but adsorb one-third the amount of water.
elements.clean_text: The main pore of HKUST-1 has a diameter of approximately 9 Å, which is quite similar to the main channel openings in CuMBTC and CuEBTC. It has been shown through experiments and molecular modeling studies that while electrostatic effects from open-metal sites play a significant role in CO2 adsorption at low pressure, van der Waals forces are still large contributors overall. Thus, the presence of the alkyl functional groups in the pore space enhances these van der Waals interactions, leading to high uptake of CO2 at low pressure. However, the alkyl groups depress water adsorption under the same conditions. As a result, compared to HKUST-1, these alkyl-functionalized MOFs have comparable CO2 and CH4 gas adsorption properties but adsorb one-third the amount of water.

elements.content: In summary, experiments have shown that the new MOFs CuMBTC and CuEBTC are promising materials for the adsorption of CO2 at low pressure. The alkyl-functionalized BTC in these MOFs significantly depresses water adsorption by a factor of 3 compared to HKUST-1, while maintaining comparable CO2 and CH4 loadings up to 5 bar. This work shows that proper functionalization of the organic ligand can lead to open-metal site MOFs with strong interactions with target gases (e.g., CO2) while lowering the interaction with water.
elements.clean_text: In summary, experiments have shown that the new MOFs CuMBTC and CuEBTC are promising materials for the adsorption of CO2 at low pressure. The alkyl-functionalized BTC in these MOFs significantly depresses water adsorption by a factor of 3 compared to HKUST-1, while maintaining comparable CO2 and CH4 loadings up to 5 bar. This work shows that proper functionalization of the organic ligand can lead to open-metal site MOFs with strong interactions with target gases (e.g., CO2) while lowering the interaction with water.

elements.content: Experimental details and 1H NMR data for compounds H3MBTC and H3EBTC, experimental details, single-crystal X-ray crystallography information (CIF), TGA analysis, and BET measurements are available for compounds CuMBTC and CuEBTC. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Experimental details and 1H NMR data for compounds H3MBTC and H3EBTC, experimental details, single-crystal X-ray crystallography information (CIF), TGA analysis, and BET measurements are available for compounds CuMBTC and CuEBTC. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Desolvation of the compounds was achieved by heating to 170 °C for 8 h under a vacuum. The MOFs undergo a color change from turquoise to dark blue, similar to HKUST-1. As shown in Figure , there is a slight difference in intensity of the peaks in the PXRD patterns after activation compared to the as-synthesized sample, but the general agreement of the major peaks, along with surface area measurements, suggests that the structures remain intact. The anhydrates are stable under dry air, and the samples rehydrate on exposure to humid air. The experimentally determined adsorption properties of CuMBTC and CuEBTC are consistent with the high porosity indicated by their crystal structures. Nitrogen isotherm measurements at 77 K gave pore volumes and BET surface areas of 0.78 cm3 g–1 and 1471 m2 g–1 for CuMBTC, and 0.65 cm3 g–1 and 1434 m2 g–1 for CuEBTC (see for N2 isotherms). The experimentally determined BET surface areas are also in good agreement with the accessible surface areas, which are 1783 m2 g–1 for CuMBTC and 1667 m2 g–1 for CuEBTC, calculated from the single-crystal structure with a nitrogen sized probe molecule.
cln_elements.clean_text: Desolvation of the compounds was achieved by heating to 170 °C for 8 h under a vacuum. The MOFs undergo a color change from turquoise to dark blue, similar to HKUST-1. As shown in Figure , there is a slight difference in intensity of the peaks in the PXRD patterns after activation compared to the as-synthesized sample, but the general agreement of the major peaks, along with surface area measurements, suggests that the structures remain intact. The anhydrates are stable under dry air, and the samples rehydrate on exposure to humid air. The experimentally determined adsorption properties of CuMBTC and CuEBTC are consistent with the high porosity indicated by their crystal structures. Nitrogen isotherm measurements at 77 K gave pore volumes and BET surface areas of 0.78 cm3 g-1 and 1471 m2 g-1 for CuMBTC, and 0.65 cm3 g-1 and 1434 m2 g-1 for CuEBTC (see  for N2 isotherms). The experimentally determined BET surface areas are also in good agreement with the accessible surface areas, which are 1783 m2 g-1 for CuMBTC and 1667 m2 g-1 for CuEBTC, calculated from the single-crystal structure with a nitrogen sized probe molecule.
